name: Checklist V (For Maritime Labour Convention, 2006)
description: A checklist to verify compliance with the Maritime Labour Convention (MLC), 2006, covering seafarers' working and living conditions.

items.text: Is the age of every seafarer not lower than 16 (or the minimum age specified in DMLC Part II, whichever is higher)?
Does every seafarer hold a valid medical certificate, dated prior to beginning work?
items.details: If the certificate expires during a voyage, the extension period should not exceed 3 months. For international voyages, the certificate must be in English.

items.text: Does the medical certificate clearly state that the seafarer is medically fit for their duties and free from any condition that could be aggravated by sea service or endanger others?
items.details: Must confirm that sight, hearing, and color vision (if applicable) are satisfactory.

items.text: Do all seafarers on board possess the required valid certifications, qualifications, and training certificates for their roles?
Is a valid Seafarers' Employment Agreement (SEA) for every crew member available on board?
items.details: A standard form of the SEA should also be available. The agreement must be in English for ships on international voyages.

items.text: Does the SEA contain all required information (shipowner's details, seafarer's details, wages, paid leave, termination conditions, repatriation entitlement, etc.)?
If a private recruitment and placement service (SRPS) was used, is there documented evidence that it is licensed, certified, or operates in compliance with MLC, 2006?
Are the records of daily hours of work or rest correctly maintained, endorsed by the master (or an authorized person) and the seafarer?
items.details: Is a copy of the record provided to each seafarer?

items.text: Are crew accommodation and on-board recreational facilities inspected at appropriate intervals, with inspection records maintained?
items.details: Inspection to be conducted by the master or a designated officer.

items.text: Are regular inspections conducted for food and drinking water supplies, storage spaces, and galley equipment, with records maintained?
Has a safe and hygienic living, working, and training environment been maintained on board?
On ships with 5 or more seafarers, is a ship safety committee held at regular intervals, with minutes recorded and issues addressed in a timely manner?
Are on-board occupational accidents, injuries, and diseases adequately inspected and reported?
Do seafarers receive free medical care and health protection services on board and in foreign ports?
items.details: Check that the ship's medicine chest, medical equipment, and medical guides are properly maintained.

items.text: Has a copy of the on-board complaint procedures been provided to all seafarers?
Do all seafarers receive their wages in full at least monthly, in accordance with their employment agreements?
Is each seafarer given a monthly account of payments due and amounts paid (including wages and any additional payments)?
Is a system in place allowing all seafarers to transmit all or part of their earnings to their families?
items.details: Any charges for such transmissions must be in accordance with flag state requirements.
